questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common endocrine tumor of the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
The most common functioning endocrine tumor of the pancreas is insulinoma. It is a tumor 
arising from the beta cells of the pancreas. The most common malignant functional neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is gastrinoma.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following statements about insulinoma is false?

options.a: Majority of insulinomas are benign and solitary
options.b: Insulinomas occur more commonly in females
options.c: Insulinomas occur more commonly in the tail, than in the head and body of pancreas
options.d: Mean age at diagnosis is 45 years

questions.explanation:
Insulinomas are distributed equally throughout the pancreas, despite the predominance of 
beta-cells in the body and tail. 803 
Sold by @itachibot The majority (90%) of insulinomas are benign and solitary, and only 10% are malignant and 
multifocal. Malignant insulinomas are usually found in association with multiple endocrine 
neoplasia (MEN) syndrome. Insulinomas are typically small, with an average size of 1.0 to 1.5 cm. Insulinomas occur more commonly in females, between 40–60 years of age with the mean age of 
diagnosis at 45 years.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not a component of Whipple's triad?

options.a: Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise
options.d: Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose

questions.explanation:
Elevated plasma levels of insulin is not a component of the triad. Whipple's triad is a clinical 
condition characterised by an insulin-producing tumour of the pancreas called insulinoma. The components of the triad are: • Symptoms of hypoglycaemia after fasting or exercise. • Plasma glucose levels <2.8 mmol/L. • Relief of symptoms on intravenous administration of glucose. Patients with insulinoma eat frequently to avoid hypoglycemic symptoms. Hence, weight loss is 
not a feature of insulinoma.

questions.question:
Question 4: The gold standard test for the diagnosis of insulinoma is  
.
questions.explanation:
The gold standard for the diagnosis of insulinoma is the 72-hour monitored fasting test. In this test, the levels of blood glucose, insulin, proinsulin, C peptide are measured in 1 to 2-hour 
intervals. When done so, a patient with insulinoma will have higher values of insulin, proinsulin, 
and C peptide which are expected to decrease in a normal person in response to the hypoglycemia 
due to fasting. All patients should be advised to undergo surgical excision of insulinoma following the exclusion 
of diffuse abdominal metastases by ultrasound or CT scan.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 50-year-old previously healthy man presents to the clinic with complaints of episodic 
palpitations, sweating, and giddiness which are relieved with food or fruit juices. Laboratory 
investigations are suggestive of insulinoma. Which of the following will be the best imaging 
modality to localize the site of the tumor in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Intra-operative ultrasound is the best method in localizing the site of the insulinoma. This is a dynamic imaging modality that provides interactive and timely information during 
surgical procedures. This is essential for the identification of small tumors, especially within the 
pancreatic head or uncinate process. Preoperatively, the site of the tumor can be assessed by endoscopic ultrasound or CT scan.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 54-year-old woman presents with recurrent attacks of dizziness and abdominal pain for 3 
months. Fasting blood glucose level was 40 mg%, and insulin levels were elevated. CT 
abdomen showed a well-defined 1 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. The treatment plan 
should be  
.
questions.explanation:
804 
Sold by @itachibot Recurrent hypoglycemic symptoms (dizziness) and low blood glucose with elevated insulin is 
suggestive of insulinoma. Tumour enucleation is the technique of choice for benign insulinomas. Insulinomas of <2 cm in diameter without signs of vascular invasion or metastases are 
considered benign. Distal pancreatectomy is advised for the following: • Tumors deep in the pancreatic body or tail • Tumors of size >2 cm • Tumors within 2 mm of the main pancreatic duct Medical management to treat hyperinsulinism includes frequent intake of carbohydrate-rich 
meals, octreotide or diazoxide.

questions.question:
Question 7: A young man with parathyroid hyperplasia and pituitary adenoma is diagnosed with multiple 
tumors in Passaro's triangle. Which of the following structures are constituents of the 
triangle?

options.a: Superior and descending duodenum, head of the pancreas, lymph nodes
options.b: Superior duodenum, head of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
options.c: Third part of the duodenum, body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach
options.d: Body of the pancreas, greater curvature of stomach, lesser curvature of stomach

questions.explanation:
The patient is most likely suffering from MEN 1 syndrome. Gastrinoma is the most common 
functional entero-pancreatic tumor in MEN1. Superior and descending duodenum, head of the 
pancreas, and lymph nodes constitute the anatomical area called gastrinoma triangle, also known 
as the Passaro's triangle. The triangle is bounded by the lines connecting: • The cystic duct • The junction between the second and third portions of the duodenum • The junction between the neck and body of the pancreas.

questions.question: Question 8: What is the most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome?
questions.explanation:
805 
Sold by @itachibot The most common site of gastrinoma in MEN 1 syndrome is the duodenum. Gastrinoma is the most common pancreatic islet tumor in MEN 1 syndrome, arising from the G 
cells of the pancreas. Gastrinoma, associated with marked gastric acid production and recurrent 
peptic ulcers, is called Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The majority of gastrinomas occur in the 
gastrinoma (Passaro's) triangle. In MEN 1, they often occur in patients <30 years. Patients present with abdominal pain (the 
most common symptom), diarrhea and steatorrhea. Management: • Medical management for tumors <2 cm with proton-pump inhibitors. • Surgery for tumors >2 cm. • Proton-pump inhibitors with somatostatin analogues for advanced locoregional disease or 
metastasis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient who had been suffering from chronic esophageal reflux and diarrhea is diagnosed 
with multiple gastrinomas. All of the following statements are true regarding his condition 
except  
.

options.a: This occurs more commonly in males
options.b: More than 60% of tumors are malignant
options.d: Surgical exploration is indicated in all patients without metastasis

questions.explanation:
Gastrinoma/Zollinger–Ellison syndrome (ZES) is a non–beta islet cell tumor of the pancreas. Option A: ZES is more common in males than in females. Option B: At the time of diagnosis, >60% of tumors are malignant. Option D: Surgical exploration should be performed in all patients without diffuse metastases, to 
remove known malignant and benign tumors.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 25-year-old man with chronic abdominal pain was brought to the casualty in a dehydrated 
state due to multiple diarrheal episodes. He was started on IV fluids and analgesics. On 
further investigation, multiple ulcers were seen in the second and third part of the duodenum 
and his serum gastrin concentration was 2000 pg/ml. Which of the following is least likely to 
be associated with this condition?

options.a: Improvement of diarrhoea following nasogastric aspiration
options.d: Reduced basal to maximal acid output ratio

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome/gastrinoma. Here, the basal 
acid output (BAO) is increased. Hence, the BAO:MAO ratio is increased. In these patients, there is gastrin hypersecretion that stimulates gastric acid secretion. This 
leads to peptic ulcers that occur at atypical sites like the duodenum and jejunum and 
are refractory and multiple. Abdominal pain is the most common complaint in these patients. However, diarrhea can occur 
due to: • Acid-induced injury to the small intestine mucosa • Inability of the intestinal tract to absorb large volumes of fluids secreted by the stomach • Inactivation of pancreatic lipase by low pH • Precipitation of bile salts. The unique characteristic of acid-induced diarrhea is that it is controlled by nasogastric aspiration 
of gastric secretions. 806 
Sold by @itachibot Gastric pH <2.5 and a serum gastrin concentration >1000 pg/mL confirm the diagnosis of 
Zollinger Ellison syndrome. If the diagnosis remains in doubt, a secretin stimulation test is done. In this test, the fasting 
gastrin level is measured before secretin (2 IU/kg) is administered intravenously, and subsequent 
samples are obtained 2, 5, 10, and 20 minutes. Gastrin levels >200 pg/mL after administration 
of secretin are suggestive of gastrinoma.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient who is recently diagnosed with Zollinger-Elison syndrome is started on proton 
pump inhibitors. There is no previous history of acid-reduction procedure done. The target 
basal acid output should be less than  
. 800 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The proton-pump inhibitor (PPI) dosage should be titrated to keep basal acid output <10 
mEq/hr in this patient. The target BAO is <5 mEq/hr if the patient has had a prior acid-reducing procedure. Ideally, the dose of proton pump inhibitors is titrated using acid output in order to improve the 
healing rate of peptic ulcer disease, and to avert its complications.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following would be the preoperative imaging study of choice in patients with 
gastrinoma?
questions.explanation:
Currently, the preoperative imaging study of choice for gastrinoma is somatostatin receptor 
scintigraphy (octreotide scan). The majority of the gastrinomas are found within the Passaro’s triangle and can be detected by 
endoscopic ultrasound (EUS). However, it still misses many of the smaller lesions, and may 
confuse normal lymph nodes for gastrinomas. If there is no tumor visible on EUS, a somatostatin receptor study is useful in identifying the 
location. When the pretest probability of gastrinoma is high, the sensitivity and specificity of this 
modality are almost 100%.

questions.question:
Question 13: Which among the following statements is false about non-functioning pancreatic endocrine 
tumors?

options.a: Most of the tumors are malignant
options.b: They account for 60-90% of all pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
options.d: They have a much better prognosis than functioning tumors

questions.explanation:
Non-functioning pancreatic endocrine tumors (NF-PETs) have a worse prognosis compared to 
functioning tumors. They account for 60-90% of all neuroendocrine tumors. They are usually larger (>5cm), 
solitary, mostly in the head of the pancreas, malignant and metastatic. These do not cause any 
clinical symptoms. They stain positive for immunohistochemical markers such as synaptophysin, chromogranin A 
(CgA), and neuron-specific enolase. Chromogranin A is used as a serum marker to monitor 
response to treatment and to detect recurrence. Treatment is mainly surgical. It includes partial pancreaticoduodenectomy as well as the 
synchronous or metachronous resection of liver metastases. 807 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 50-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a skin lesion as shown in the image below. 
The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and the abdomen. She 
has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis 
despite anticoagulation therapy. What is the most likely diagnosis? 801 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image depicts necrolytic migratory erythema. This skin lesion along with a history of 
long-standing diabetes and recurrent deep vein thrombosis is suggestive of glucagonoma.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 49-year-old female patient presents with complaints of abdominal pain and foul-smelling, 
greasy stools for one year. She is known to be diabetic and underwent cholecystectomy one 
year back. CT scan shows the presence of a tumor in the pancreas. What is the most probable 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The most probable diagnosis is somatostatinoma. Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usually 
present with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of: • Gallstones - due to bile stasis • Diabetes - due to inhibition of insulin secretion • Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion.

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with MEN 1 syndrome is diagnosed with VIPoma. Which of the following is not 
seen in this condition?

options.a: It is associated with failure of complete rotation of the ventral bud
options.b: Can be associated with classic double bubble sign on radiograph
options.c: Duodenoduodenostomy is the treatment of choice
options.d: MRCP is the gold standard investigation

questions.explanation:
VIPoma is associated with achlorhydria. Vasoactive intestinal peptide-secreting tumor (VIPoma) is also known as Verner–Morrison 
syndrome/WDHA syndrome. WDHA stands for: • WD - Watery Diarrhea • H – Hypokalemia • A – Achlorhydria Metabolic acidosis from fluid and bicarbonate loss is common in VIPoma. 808 
Sold by @itachibot Congenital Anomalies and Acute Pancreatitis
